This one workout will keep you amped up all week long. Seriously, give it a try and you will be hooked!


The exercises may change from week to week, but it is always a Tabata-style interval workout: 20 seconds of high intensity work followed by 10 seconds of rest. Then repeat! Exercises include sprints, burpees, squats, situps, box jumps, step ups, pushups, dips, and other “no-frills” exercises.


Warm up beforehand by running, biking, or walking. We start promptly at 6:30 AM and the workout only lasts 31 minutes. Show up a few minutes early to meet people and get yourself pumped up.

results.description:
Every week we will have a different prompt for our weekly photo project.  This week’s theme is The view from here

Each week beginning early Monday morning, you can begin uploading your photos to our meetup album for the week’s theme.  The group won’t actually meet for this event, it’s an individual online challenge for each of you to get your creative juices flowing, share photos in the group, comment and critique each other’s shots, and above all have fun. 

Albums will remain open, so you can upload photos any time after that Monday morning start time but you’ll get the most feedback during the initial week the theme is posted.  You also don’t have to restrict yourself to photos taken during that week for the theme, they can be from past shoots you have done or the weekly prompt can be used to motivate you to shoot something new.

Please consider sharing your project photos with our other chapters on our Facebook group.
results.name: Weekly Photo Project - The view from here

results.description:
The New York City Economic Development Corporation (NYC EDC) and B Lab have launched the Best for NYC program to celebrate and support businesses that positively influence their workers, their community, and the environment. Participants are asked to take the "challenge" and fill out a brief survey about their business practices. Those who participate will be recognized by the city in an online and print directory, and will have access to special events and other benefits. 

In this workshop, the EDC will present details about the program and guide participants through the process of filling out the challenge. By the end of this workshop, we hope that everyone attending will be signed up and eligible for the program. 

Goodnik has partnered with the Impact Hub NYC , the Centre for Social Innovation, and Be Social Change to host these workshops because because we support and promote socially responsible business practices and want to encourage all our members to do business in a better way. You don't need to attend the workshop to take the challenge - take it on your own today!

TAKE THE BEST FOR NYC CHALLENGE


Special benefits for Goodnik members who take the challenge;

• A "service grant" of 100 goodnikels, to be used for 10 hours of professional services at Goodnik.net.

• Free tickets to Be Social Change events and 20% off BSC classes through March 15, 2016

• One week of free coworking at the Centre for Social Innovation or Impact Hub NYC for non-members

• Exclusive events and parties 

• Inclusion in ‘Best for NYC’ Guide (print & digital), reaching 150,000+

• Exclusive events and services

• The opportunity to be featured in citywide awards and press*

• Membership in a vibrant networking community

• Ability to use ‘Best for NYC’ participant logo

• Tools to benchmark performance and create improvement plans
results.name: Best for NYC Workshop

Portraits On-The-Go

Please stop in the Adorama store between 3 PM and 7 PM on February 29th, to see, touch, try, and discuss with Steven Rossi, a vast array of essential photographic gear by BlackRapid Straps, Hoodman Anti-Glare Products and Steel Memory Cards and Photoflex Light Modifiers. In the store, Steven will show you the best way to setup for Portraits On-The-Go, so bring your camera and take some shots with him!
BlackRapid Straps keep your camera safely out-of-the-way when hustling to and setting up the shot, and always at hand’s reach the instant it’s time to capture the shot!
Hoodman Anti-Glare Products such as HoodEyes that eliminate the distraction from extraneous light while locking your eye to the center of your viewfinder, and inherently assist in stabilizing your camera for the sharpest shot; and HoodLoupes that eliminate glare while inspecting your shots on your camera’s LCD as well as when you shoot in Live View and Video Modes; and Steel Memory Cards that are the most durable and among the fastest cards available!
Photoflex Light Modifiers such as high quality speed-light soft-boxes and white-rimmed portable reflectors used to simulate natural light as well as shape and redirect light without casting any unwanted elements onto your subject—so you can paint your subject in its absolute best light!

Steven Rossi, working in the photographic industry for over 30 years, is a portrait and nature photographer, and represents BlackRapid, Hoodman and Photoflex in NYC. Please view his work and follow him at: Instagram: srossi_photography , www.500px.com/srofny ,
and www.stevenrossiphotography.zenfolio.com !

results.description:
Our twice-monthly meeting of business professionals takes place from 4pm - 5pm in a private meeting room at the restaurant.

While there are many ways to make connections with potential new clients, nothing is better than having that prospect's trusted advisor pick up a phone or send an e-mail that says, "Here's someone you need to speak with about that problem you're having".  This is exactly what the members of Smart Transition Group do for each other.  We get to know each other, we get to trust each other, and then we share our most valuable resource... our clients.  

We all want to grow our businesses, but doing it personally, face-to-face, with people you trust and appreciate, makes it faster, easier, and far more effective.  Come learn more as a guest of the group at one of our upcoming meetings.  Bring your best-self, and a stack of business cards.

We'll take an opportunity to introduce ourselves and get to know other members. We will often have a featured member who will expand on the details of their business and help us to understand their buying signs so that we know who to think of when we hear them from our clients.

After a good discussion and a recap of the progress we will retire to the bar at Morton's for a drink and a more relaxed discussion. Some say, that's where the business really happens.

This is a great way to spend some time on a Monday afternoon growing your network and building alliances.
results.name: Monday Meetings at Morton's (The Steakhouse)

group.name: Smart Transition Group - Business Networking that Works

results.description:
Procedural Generation ("Proc-gen") in games relies heavily on programmatic techniques to create worlds. The workshop will be led by Braden Gammon who will go over Processing, a wrapper for the Java programming language, and an analysis of No Man's Sky , which incorporates proc-gen. 

There will be a short presentation on the fundamentals of procgen, followed by two demos, and two case studies of games that owe their popularity to proc-gen. In the demos, you will be guided through creating and tweaking rules to make your own proc-gen world.

Braden Gammon is a junior at New York University, double-majoring in Computer Science and Game Design, as well as a support player. If you love gaming, than you won't want to miss this event!

Who is this for?

Ideally, no prior experience is needed to come listen and ask any questions you have about what proc-gen is and how it is currently used in games.

The “Creating Rules” and “Creating Worlds” exercises have templates that will help you follow along if you are new to programming, but will also be flexible enough to allow you to create the next "No Man's Sky" in 30 minutes if you have the necessary skills!


 How to prepare

Proc-gen in games relies heavily on programmatic techniques to create worlds. The demos will use Processing, a wrapper for the Java programming language, which is an Object-Oriented Programming language. You certainly do not need to have a deep understanding of OOP in order to understand the demos, but knowledge of basic programming constructs like variables and methods will help you out.

Halfway through each demo, there will be 2-3 minutes for anyone who is having trouble to ask questions or get help debugging their program. The point of the demos is to observe how tweaking rulesets in small ways can make great changes to a procedurally generated world.


What to bring

Both demos will use Processing. To run the demos, you will need a computer with Processing 3.0.2 installed. Here is the download.
You should also download beforehand the template code for both demos --- link released this weekend. 

I will assume that you know how to do the following things:

• Open a Processing project folder.

• Create a new tab in Processing.

• Run a Processing project.

If you aren’t feeling confident about the above points, you can read this brief tutorial.

results.description:
"To practice Zen means to realize one’s existence moment after moment, rather than letting life unravel in regret of the past or daydreaming of the future.

To “rest in the present” is a state of magical simplicity, although attainment of this state is not as simple as it sounds. At the very least, sitting Zen practice, called zazen, will bring about a strong sense of well-being, as the clutter of ideas & emotions falls away and body & mind return to natural harmony with all creation.  Out of this emptiness can come a true insight into the nature of existence, which is no different from one’s Buddha nature." —Peter Mattheissen

A weekly Meditation Group in the Zen Tradition.

Open to All!

Every Monday

5:30 — Beginning Instruction
(If You are new to Meditation/Zen style or want a refresher, please arrive a few minutes early)

6:00 — Zazen/Seated Meditation (*)

6:25 — Walking Meditation (*)

6:35 — Zazen/Seated Meditation (*)

7:00 — Talk / Discussion (*)

(*) — Possible to join the evening at any time.

results.description:
***NOTE*** This group is currently full and we are not accepting new players.

INTRODUCTION:


The truth about the Keys of Power has long since been discarded as just so much myth and legend. But one of those Keys has just resurfaced and numerous factions are dead-set on possessing it. This means certain doom for the poor souls who've stumbled upon it.

Are these unfortunate souls mere pawns in a greater game? Do they even know of that which fate has cast their way?

If they are truly unaware of the significance of that which they now possess, it would be to their benefit to become aware of it. Fate and destiny have converged upon them and, before long, many will vie to possess the item they hold. Many will seek to become the Keeper of the Keys and our intrepid adventurers stand in their way.

BACKGROUND:

"The Keeper of the Keys" is a home-brewed, Dungeons and Dragons campaign. I am looking to run this campaign as part of the Edison MeetUp group. However, I cannot run/attend a weekly game. My schedule simply does not allow for it.

So I'm setting this group up as a bi-weekly game; sort-of. Specifically, I will schedule a recurring MeetUp for the first and third Monday of each month beginning with February 15th, 2016. I will also schedule a bonus MeetUp for the fifth Monday of those months that have five Mondays. This means our first four meetings will be February 15th & 29th and March 7th & 21st.

I am looking for a group of players willing to commit to the schedule I propose; players whose attendance will not be an issue. These players also need to be ready to be involved in a long-running game.

Each time I've run "The Keeper of the Keys", it's encompassed almost the entirety of the PC's lifespan as adventurers. In other words, if you join and stay in my game, you can be fairly certain it won't end until your character has reached the maximum level of experience.

Come for the sheer joy of moving to the music, in a nurturing and supportive setting.

Whether you have never danced before or want to continue, this is a class for you.

The classes are one hour and half in length and provide quality instruction.

Ballet is one of the most healthy and intense forms of dance.
It can provide a complete full-body workout, increasing your flexibility, range of motion and strength.

It’s also a great alternative to aerobics.

The classes are on-going, join in anytime.

PRICES Walk-Ins: $20.
Package: $180 for a card of 10 classes (over a course of 6 months).
Talk to us about multiple class per week discount!

ABOUT THE INSTRUCTOR
Bruce Weitzmon is a choreographer, dancer and teacher. His work has been presented in the U.S.A. and Canada. Bruce was the director of the Theater Dance Center, a non-profit dance education and performance organization in Rockland County, founded in 1981. After many years directing TDC, he returned to New York City to teach. Now after more than 10 years there, he is returning to offer a weekly schedule of classes in Nyack, NY.

results.description:
NOTE. RSVP-ing here is NOT sufficient. You must email or call the reservation line.

Latest Discoveries at Pluto and Mars


2015 heralded astonishing discoveries in the Solar System. The spacecraft New Horizons flew by Pluto, giving humanity its first pictures of the Ninth Planet. The journey was 9 years to get to Pluto, and the discoveries were beyond what anyone had expected. Jason Kendall will highlight the trip and what was found, as well as giving a bit of background to the battle over the word “planet.” Then he will take us to Mars, where Curiosity has been roaming the surface, seeking signs of past habitability of Mars. The recent confirmation of current, seasonal water flows on Mars only raises our own desire to set foot on this not-so-alien world. Through the rovers and orbiters, we see a place that is quite familiar, and that popular media as well as serious explorers hope to put feet on the ground of the red planet within the next 20 to 30 years. We’ll discuss the nature of the past conditions on Mars and how they were discovered and how humans may soon reach out and grasp the dirt of the Red Planet with their own hands.

Jason Kendall is currently adjunct faculty at William Paterson University teaching astronomy. He holds a Master of Science in Astronomy from New Mexico State University and a Master of Fine Arts in Theater from the University of Texas at Austin. This unique combination has propelled him to be one of the foremost astronomy and science popularizers in the US. As a board member of the Amateur Astronomers Association of New York since 2008, Jason has led the over 200 events of stargazing and public astronomy outreach to upper Manhattan, including the historic Inwood Star Fest, where Inwood Hill Park lights were turned off as part of the 100 Hours of Astronomy event in IYA2009. This was the first time in New York City history when park lights were turned off for an astronomy event. Jason also focused on park safety due to an uptick in sexual assaults in Washington Heights and Inwood during 2011. Jason’s start in astronomy was back in the fourth grade by the encouragement of two noted astronomers, Charles Schweighauser and Bart Bok. After seeing Saturn through Charlie's telescope at Sangamon State University on a clear Illinois night, and with Bart’s encouragement and confidence, Jason studied astronomy to walk in their footsteps. This is not just a scientific journey, as Jason’s great-grandfather was a Midwestern minister who used to preach his sermons out under the dark, cloudless nights. Landy Haven always believed that getting out and experiencing the wonders of the natural world was a central part of being a complete person. Landy’s profound words under the stars continue to guide Jason in his quest to share the night sky as "We look up to look within." jasonkendall.com

Chers ami(e)s,

Thank you for making our now WEEKLY event "Jadore le French" a great success : c’était ma première surprise partie :-) Pictures posted below ! Let's meet again at Cellar Bar to speak French (or at least try a bit with Manhattans).

Special Thanks&HugsⓇ to the new members : you guys rock !Congratulations to Gabor and Abderaman, winners of the last raffle.

MegaHugsⓇ to Amelia, Hostess Etincelante, inventor of a new game using French quotes. 

French is not such a difficult language. If Rocky Balboa can speak Russian, if Rambo can speak Dari, then everybody can speak French, just a question of time :-) The new format "Jadore-le-French" is even nicer than our "Pardon-my-French" of last year.

To facilitate connections and meet&greets, we will have a special fun "lottery" :

Each of you will be given one of my polaroids (http://myinstantfilms.com/). Only TWO PAIRS will be identical. The 4 winners will get an invitation for two at Crepes & Delices, a brand new French crêperie located on 72nd and Columbus. THEY DO HAVE REAL GALETTES DE SARRASIN, AVIS AUX AMATEURS :

http://crepesanddelices.com


Come and get rewards by :

1. Dressing super nicely

2. Showing progress in your French skills (whatever you start from)

None of these are an obligation, neither a demand, just an incentive for rewards (perfumes, hats, free bottles of wine etc.).

Who are the organizers ? Yara, Handsome President, and Jean-Philippe, Glorieux Président. Since 3 weeks, Amelia, aka Superamelia, has joined the team as Hostess Étincelante.

IN THREE YEARS, WE HAVE ORGANIZED HUNDREDS OF SOCIAL EVENTS, FRENCH LESSONS/WORKSHOPS, FRENCH CONCERTS (including launching Flo, now superstar!) etc.

Pics from last Jadore le French :

Merci beaucoup et à lundi prochain !

-- Jean-Philippe, Yara, Amelia

results.description:
Please note that our group and our happy hours are not for non-Asians. 

Icebreaker Game: "Find a Match"

We are continuing the seventh round of our icebreaker game.  As before, the game will start at 6:30 pm and will run until 7:30 pm. The first 25 matches will get a free drink ticket each! Here are the rules: 

1. You must write your first and last name on the name tags. If you are looking for a career match, you must also write the company or industry for which you work. 

2. You must find your match in one of the following ways: 

a. CAREER: Find someone in your industry or in an industry to which you would want to transition. Tell that person why you want to work with them. If that person wants to work with you too, make arrangements to have coffee or meet together between this NYAPM happy hour and the next one. Once you have made plans with a date, time, and place, find the organizers for your free drink ticket. 

OR 

b. DATING: Find someone you would like to go on a first date with. Tell that person why you would like to date them. If that person wants to go on a first date with you too, make arrangements for your first date between this NYAPM Happy Hour and the next one. Once you have made plans with a date, time, and place, find the organizers for your free drink ticket. 

Once you have completed 1 and 2(a) or 2(b) above, find one of the organizers (Richard Young) or (Tiffany Ma) to get your free drinks (available only for the first 25 matches – so come on time!).

--

Our monthly happy hour is our flagship event that started it all years ago in 2005. Experience what it's all about -- come and meet fellow Asian professionals in a friendly, casual atmosphere. Relax after work and meet some new people.

Because this is a free event where you are not paying a cover or door fee, we humbly request that you please buy one drink or more to support our venue since they are turning away other business to allow us to host our event (buying alcoholic drinks/soft drinks/bottled water helps support the venue -- getting free tap/iced water does not).

First time to one of our events?  See photos from previous happy hours on Meetup or Facebook.

Hope to see you there!

Also find us on Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/events/833965663378452/
results.name: February 2016 NYAPM Happy Hour

The hottest stand-up show in LA is now in NYC. The show is called Supply and Demand and was just featured by Time Out Los Angeles. In Los Angeles, most of the shows are sold out, and the show was featured on ESPN, when SportsNation's Michelle Beadle did a special surprise set. Past surprise guests include Howie Mandel, Jerrod Carmichael, Pete Holmes, and Whitney Cummings!

The show is normally $20, but we have $5 tickets for the group. INSTRUCTIONS YOU NEED TO FOLLOW!

1) RSVPing is not enough! To get the tickets, visit http://www.GothamComedyClub.com with the code MEETUPFIVE and follow the checkout instructions - you must do this BEFORE the day of the show.

2) When you arrive, go to the box office podium. Tell them you're there for the meetup and you already have tickets (and your name is on the list). It's a 7PM curtain, but we're meeting up early (at 6PM).

results.description:
NOTE. RSVP-ing here is NOT sufficient. You must email or call the reservation line.

Latest Discoveries at Pluto and Mars


2015 heralded astonishing discoveries in the Solar System. The spacecraft New Horizons flew by Pluto, giving humanity its first pictures of the Ninth Planet. The journey was 9 years to get to Pluto, and the discoveries were beyond what anyone had expected. Jason Kendall will highlight the trip and what was found, as well as giving a bit of background to the battle over the word “planet.” Then he will take us to Mars, where Curiosity has been roaming the surface, seeking signs of past habitability of Mars. The recent confirmation of current, seasonal water flows on Mars only raises our own desire to set foot on this not-so-alien world. Through the rovers and orbiters, we see a place that is quite familiar, and that popular media as well as serious explorers hope to put feet on the ground of the red planet within the next 20 to 30 years. We’ll discuss the nature of the past conditions on Mars and how they were discovered and how humans may soon reach out and grasp the dirt of the Red Planet with their own hands.

Jason Kendall is currently adjunct faculty at William Paterson University teaching astronomy. He holds a Master of Science in Astronomy from New Mexico State University and a Master of Fine Arts in Theater from the University of Texas at Austin. This unique combination has propelled him to be one of the foremost astronomy and science popularizers in the US. As a board member of the Amateur Astronomers Association of New York since 2008, Jason has led the over 200 events of stargazing and public astronomy outreach to upper Manhattan, including the historic Inwood Star Fest, where Inwood Hill Park lights were turned off as part of the 100 Hours of Astronomy event in IYA2009. This was the first time in New York City history when park lights were turned off for an astronomy event. Jason also focused on park safety due to an uptick in sexual assaults in Washington Heights and Inwood during 2011. Jason’s start in astronomy was back in the fourth grade by the encouragement of two noted astronomers, Charles Schweighauser and Bart Bok. After seeing Saturn through Charlie's telescope at Sangamon State University on a clear Illinois night, and with Bart’s encouragement and confidence, Jason studied astronomy to walk in their footsteps. This is not just a scientific journey, as Jason’s great-grandfather was a Midwestern minister who used to preach his sermons out under the dark, cloudless nights. Landy Haven always believed that getting out and experiencing the wonders of the natural world was a central part of being a complete person. Landy’s profound words under the stars continue to guide Jason in his quest to share the night sky as "We look up to look within." jasonkendall.com
Date: February 29, 2016

Time: 6:00 pm Reception, 7:00 pm Lecture

Location: Club Headquarters, 46 East 70th Street, New York, NY, 10021

Member Ticket price: $10

Guest Ticket Price: $25

Student Ticket Price:

$5 w/ a valid Student ID

Reservation Notes:

Reservations are allotted on a first-come, first-serve basis.

To secure a reservation, please call us at[masked] or email us at [masked].

results.description:
Since it only comes once every 4 years, why not celebrate the leap year with some hot chocolate. The City Bakery has an annual Hot Chocolate Festival where they serve a different flavor of hot chocolate everyday of the month. Monday is the last day of the festival and the flavor is leap year festival... We don't know what that tastes like either. So obviously, there's only one way to find out! Join us as we discover what this mystery flavor is all about. We promise this event will not be rescheduled. The weather isn't supposed to be too cold. Please RSVP if you plan to attend.

**Accessibility info**

We checked out the venue and it has limited accessibility. The entrance is accessible but it tends to get loud, crowded and the isles are tight. The bathrooms have an accessibility symbol but the toilets are not accessible. We wanted to share this information with you so you can plan accordingly. We apologize for this and will choose more accessible venues in the future. Yelp link and phone number to City Bakery are below.

http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-city-bakery-new-York

Phone:[masked]

The closes accessible train station is 14th street Union Square. Use the link below to check for elevator outages.

http://advisory.mtanyct.info/EEoutage/

Also stay tuned for meetups in March. There will be a meetup at the Reelabilities Film Festival and Karaoke on the 19th. As always, if you have any accessibility requests or meetup suggestions, feel free to contact an organizer.

 Walei
results.name: Hot Chocolate Festival at The City Bakery

results.description:
THIS EVENT IS CLOSED FULLY BOOKED & MOVED TO 3rd FLOOR  TO LARGER SPACE :  PLEASE REGISTER FOR OUR NEXT EVENTS  MARCH 8th, 16th or our TWO NIGHT SPECIAL "PITCH" EVENT WITH SPECIAL GUEST HSN APRIL 12 th & 13th at 6:00-8:00 p.m. HELD AT MICROSOFT.....

ANDREA ROSE  IS EXCITED TO ANNOUNCE WE HAVE TEAMED UP  WITH HSN!

TO ALL INVENTORS WITH THAT GREAT "IDEA"YOUR INVITED TO "PITCH A PRODUCT™".  ANDREA ROSE® & HER PARTNERS ARE LOOKING FOR THAT NEXT GREAT PRODUCT TO BRING TO MARKET!!

We are excited to announce at ‘The Inventors Road Show™” our  workshop “Pitch a Product™”.   Award winning inventor Andrea Rose® will facilitate the evening helping the group  learn how to present their products to market while on the lookout for that next “Winning” product to introduce to her marketing associates that include such companies as "As Seen On TV , mass retailers. international distributors and television home shopping companies to name a few. We are excited to announce we have teamed up with HSN!!!


Attendees will have “5 minutes” to pitch their inventions to the group.  This workshop helps inventors learn how to present their “Ideas to Industry™”.  It also helps them discover how to look at their inventions as a solution to a problem that is needed in the marketplace.  To have a successful  “product/invention”  it must fill a need in the marketplace and this workshop explores this very important aspect of inventing. The evening will discuss various topics that provide the attendees with the tools they will need  to turn their "Idea" into a commercial success.  All inventors are welcome!!!

NOTE:  Andrea Rose® is an award winning inventor who has alliances with companies that provide services to inventors.  We at "The Inventors Road Show" are excited to announce we  have teamed up with HSN!!  Andrea will be providing the group with her expert advice and looking for the next great invention to present to her marketing associates.  Andrea does one on one consulting for inventors who are seeking personalize assistance.  For more information contact:  [masked]

(From time to time there will be surprise guests who will join Andrea Rose® at the workshops.)

DISCLAIMER:  Andrea Rose® is not an attorney and does not provide any legal advice to any inventor. All inventors  pitching and presenting their inventions in the workshop should have filed for a provisional patent, have a patent-pending or an issued patent if they choose to participate in giving a pitch to the group.  Otherwise their idea could loose the legal  protection that is provided by filing for a patent.  It will be at the discretion of the inventor if they want to pitch their product.

For more information email us at: [masked]

results.description:
Hi hardwarians,

What better way to celebrate a leap year than to have a hardware meetup on Feb 29th! We've got some great startups for you again this month - the NY hardware scene is just getting better and better. And remember to stay for the beers afterwards!

Agenda:

6:00 - 6:15pm: arrival, pizza and beer

6:15 - 6:25pm: welcome and sponsors

6:25 - 6:45pm: Chris Rill, CTO and cofounder of Canary, will talk about their journey going from 2 cofounders and an idea, to a company with 94 employees selling Canaries in over 7000 retail stores in the US, and all this within 2 years.

6:45- 7:05pm: Matteo Franceschetti, CEO and cofounder of Eight,  the smart mattress cover to enable better sleep. He will talk about creating the company out of StartX, Stanford's incubator, getting into YCombinator and then crushing it with an Indiegogo campaign.

7:05 - 7:20pm: Ismail Salhi, cofounder of Qleek, an original and beautiful way to share and collect your music. Qleeks are physical bookmarks to online music.

7:20pm - onwards: networking and community announcements.

See you all there!

Haytham
results.name: 32nd Hardware Meetup

results.description:
Bring your laptop! 

We're using the Flatiron School's online Full Stack Web Development program, starting with the free Intro to Ruby Development track. We highly recommend that you create your account and get your feet wet with the platform before you arrive! 

The format of this Meetup will be loose since this is the first one. We'll have some munchies. We'll start with some introductions followed by a quick discussion about some recent tech news. Then everyone will jump into the curriculum wherever they are (there will be a wide range of levels present including total newbie!). Collaboration and questions are encouraged. We'll have some monitors available for pair programming. 

All levels welcome! Positivity and friendliness required. :-)

He holds a Master of Science in Astronomy from New Mexico State University and a Master of Fine Arts in Theater from the University of Texas at Austin. This unique combination has propelled him to be one of the foremost astronomy and science popularizers in the US. As a board member of the Amateur Astronomers Association of New York since 2008, Jason has led the over 200 events of stargazing and public astronomy outreach to upper Manhattan, including the historic Inwood Star Fest, where Inwood Hill Park lights were turned off as part of the 100 Hours of Astronomy event in IYA2009. This was the first time in New York City history when park lights were turned off for an astronomy event. Jason also focused on park safety due to an uptick in sexual assaults in Washington Heights and Inwood during 2011. Jason’s start in astronomy was back in the fourth grade by the encouragement of two noted astronomers, Charles Schweighauser and Bart Bok. After seeing Saturn through Charlie's telescope at Sangamon State University on a clear Illinois night, and with Bart’s encouragement and confidence, Jason studied astronomy to walk in their footsteps. This is not just a scientific journey, as Jason’s great-grandfather was a Midwestern minister who used to preach his sermons out under the dark, cloudless nights. Landy Haven always believed that getting out and experiencing the wonders of the natural world was a central part of being a complete person. Landy’s profound words under the stars continue to guide Jason in his quest to share the night sky as "We look up to look within." jasonkendall.com

Location: Club Headquarters, 46 East 70th Street, New York, NY, 10021

Member Ticket price: $10

Guest Ticket Price: $25

Student Ticket Price:

$5 w/ a valid Student ID

results.description:
Latest Discoveries at Pluto and Mars

NOTE. RSVP-ing here is NOT sufficient. You must email or call the reservation line.

2015 heralded astonishing discoveries in the Solar System. The spacecraft New Horizons flew by Pluto, giving humanity its first pictures of the Ninth Planet. The journey was 9 years to get to Pluto, and the discoveries were beyond what anyone had expected. Jason Kendall will highlight the trip and what was found, as well as giving a bit of background to the battle over the word “planet.” Then he will take us to Mars, where Curiosity has been roaming the surface, seeking signs of past habitability of Mars. The recent confirmation of current, seasonal water flows on Mars only raises our own desire to set foot on this not-so-alien world. Through the rovers and orbiters, we see a place that is quite familiar, and that popular media as well as serious explorers hope to put feet on the ground of the red planet within the next 20 to 30 years. We’ll discuss the nature of the past conditions on Mars and how they were discovered and how humans may soon reach out and grasp the dirt of the Red Planet with their own hands.

Jason Kendall is currently adjunct faculty at William Paterson University teaching astronomy. He holds a Master of Science in Astronomy from New Mexico State University and a Master of Fine Arts in Theater from the University of Texas at Austin. This unique combination has propelled him to be one of the foremost astronomy and science popularizers in the US. As a board member of the Amateur Astronomers Association of New York since 2008, Jason has led the over 200 events of stargazing and public astronomy outreach to upper Manhattan, including the historic Inwood Star Fest, where Inwood Hill Park lights were turned off as part of the 100 Hours of Astronomy event in IYA2009. This was the first time in New York City history when park lights were turned off for an astronomy event. Jason also focused on park safety due to an uptick in sexual assaults in Washington Heights and Inwood during 2011. Jason’s start in astronomy was back in the fourth grade by the encouragement of two noted astronomers, Charles Schweighauser and Bart Bok. After seeing Saturn through Charlie's telescope at Sangamon State University on a clear Illinois night, and with Bart’s encouragement and confidence, Jason studied astronomy to walk in their footsteps. This is not just a scientific journey, as Jason’s great-grandfather was a Midwestern minister who used to preach his sermons out under the dark, cloudless nights. Landy Haven always believed that getting out and experiencing the wonders of the natural world was a central part of being a complete person. Landy’s profound words under the stars continue to guide Jason in his quest to share the night sky as "We look up to look within." jasonkendall.com

results.description:
* This is a online recruiting drive to help connect top data talent with top opportunities *

Candidate Signup Page: http://pxl.me/dtdc

Recruiter Signup Page: http://pxl.me/dtdr

This is an online first and offline once selected event.. Please visit: http://dtd.analyticsweek.com for more information.

AnalyticsWeek's Analytics.Club is bringing biggest data talent draft day to town. On last day of every month top data and analytics talent applicant will be drafted for interview and invited to showcase their data talent in front of cutting edge big data companies. Analytics.Club Data Talent Draft works tirelessly to connect top talent with top recruiting companies.

No awkword lines, no haggling to get heard, no competing with noise, and One easy process to connect top talent with top opportunities.

When: Draft begins every Last day of every month. Starting 6:00pm

Where: In your own city. 

Process: 

For Talent 

1. Applicant apply using Job Seeker form till last day of the month

2. Recruiters will get anonymized information and asked to pick drafts by following week

3. Chosen draft candidates will be contacted in 3 following weeks for an interview

If you're DRAFTED interewed and will make the cut, we have some awesome swags for you. 

For Recruiter 

1. Recruiter signup using the form below

2. We will share anonymized candidate info and give a week to pick shortlisted candidates

3. Once recruiter shortlist winning profile, we will ask the candidate and send introduction

Draft the Top Picked Talent and share your success with us. 

How can I participate? 

It's simple. If you are a job-seeker, just Register here and fill the form. Be sure to put your best foot forward to make yourself shine while filling the form. That's it. You're done. On Draft Day, if you are lucky you should hear from one of the top companies partnering with us. Don't be discouraged if you don't hear from anyone as the draft will happen last day of every month. 

If you are a recruiter, then register here with your requirements and company details.

-> Data Talent Draft Recruiter Signup

Summer Hours: 5pm – 7pm (July and August only).

Nafisa Sharriff is a Master Teacher and Choreographer of Traditional West African Folklore from the Old Malian Empire. She is the recipient of the 1996 Ethnic Dance Award and numerous Community Service commemorations. Throughout her illustrious career Nafisa performed with Stevie Wonder, Whitney Houston, Spike Lee, TC Carson, C&C Music Factory, The Chuck Davis Dance Company & The Kairaba West African Dance Company. results.description:
Our weekly Meet Up will take place at Scotty's Steakhouse and Comedy Cove in Springfield, just a bit off of exit 9B on Route 24! The address is 595 Morris Ave, Springfield.


There is a world of gaming outside of the traditional Monopoly, Scrabble, Risk, etc. Whether you're looking for something new and different, or you're a seasoned gamer, you'll find a friendly and welcoming bunch of friends to game with.  Be adventurous , come learn some new games or play your favorites!

We begin gathering around 6:30 pm and are fully underway by 7pm.

Because the event takes place at a restaurant that serves alcohol, there are strict rules against gambling of any form.  Guests under 21 are welcome, as it is a restaurant. Since they are letting us use the space for free, they expect that we will order food and drink, so there are some rules:

1.  No outside food or drink, not even bottled water.

2. Please plan on ordering food and/or drinks.  Support the venue.

3. Tip the waitstaff generously.  15% is standard, but 20% is even better. We want them to love having us there, and in this case, money does buy you love.


4. If you plan on attending regularly, please consider a small contribution to cover The Tipsy Meeple's costs for using Meetup.

We bring some of our games, but feel free to bring your favorites, or learn one of ours! And don't be shy about learning new games, we are more than willing to teach a new player! Can't wait to see you there.

results.description:
(This event is currently full, but please feel free to RSVP for the waitlist. We anticipate that more spots will open up.)

Vegetarian/vegan company and karaoke - there are few combinations better than that! So where is a great karaoke place in NYC? Many places only have rooms available, which can be expensive, some places are very cramped, and other karaoke bars just lack a fun, exciting vibe. Radio Star Karaoke in Midtown fits the definition of a perfect karaoke bar: it has private rooms AND a spacious karaoke area by the bar with a stage, it has an interesting and unique retro atmosphere with fun disco lighting, and there are great songs to choose from! See song list here. Also, during happy hour (Mon-Thu, 3pm-8pm), it costs $1 per song rather than the usual $2 per song!


According to their website: "Radio Star Karaoke & Bar features original vintage high end entertainment decor located in the heart of the Fashion District and Midtown Manhattan. We host a 550 sq. feet bar with a stage. A total of 9 private rooms with diverse space to fit parties of 4 to 40 guests." 


An article in gothamist titled, The 8 Best Karaoke Spots In NYC, listed Radio Star Karaoke as one of the 8 best spots: "For an "upscale" karaoke experience, this Midtown spot's got all the fixings: party rooms, funky vintage decor and an open bar drink deal for those who need all the liquid courage they can get to ease their performance anxiety. Though Radio Star's song list isn't as extensive as some of its Koreatown counterparts, the space itself is massive is enough to make up for it, boasting nine or so private rooms ranging from 4 people to about 40 people...in addition to a main bar for collective singers."

NewYork.com also listed Radio Star Karaoke as one of the 5 best karaoke bars in NYC, and New York Eater states, "A step above the average Koreatown karaoke bar, Radio Star boasts a large selection of music, high tech visuals, and acoustics, as well as some old timey radios for decor."

NYC The Official Guide (nycgo.com) mentions Radio Star Karaoke in an article titled, untrained melody: where to sing karaoke in nyc. The article states, "The vintage decor is the epitome of cool, and half-price karaoke during happy hour (Monday through Thursday 3–8pm) gives tune time more than just weekend appeal."

Come on out for an evening full of songs, laughter, and friendship! 


Note: Please check the website barnivore.com to verify that the drink you order is vegan and ask the bar staff to point out the vegan food options if you choose to order food at the bar. 

For those of you who have never attended one of our Meetup events: this is an incredibly friendly & welcoming group. It will be easy to find our group: we are essentially taking over the majority of the bar.  Also everyone pays for their own drinks/food. Easy!

Where to find us: We will be at the tables right at the front of the bar, by the stage. Look for the "VEG MEETUP" signs on the tables. Some of us may also be at the bar, look for a sign there too. You don't have to arrive right at 6:30pm, but it is helpful if you can. Those people who arrive at 6:30pm will save seats for those arriving later.


Train directions: Take the B, D, F, M, N, Q, or R train to 34th St. - Herald Square, the 4, 5, or 6 trains to 33rd St., or the 1, 2, or 3 train to 34th St. - Penn Station. Radio Star Karaoke is located on 35th St. between 5th and 6th Avenues.

Look forward to seeing you there!

Kelsey
results.how_to_find_us: How to find us: Come inside the bar and we will be sitting at the tables. We will have a "meetup" sign so that you may find us easily.
results.name: Vegetarian/Vegan Karaoke Night at Radio Star Karaoke (Limited Attendance)

results.description:
Like our Facebook Page!:

    facebook.com/ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

Game description: 

Teams are 4 V 4, no goalies, no gender requirements (but we'd like at least 1 female player per team). Games will be played on a 1st goal rotation basis or 15 minutes time limit. The team that scores first stays on  the field. But if your team remains on the field after scoring 3 goals, we'll split the team up so that everyone has a fair chance to have a great game.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! 

VERY IMPORTANT: 

- NO FOULS

- NO SIDE TACKLING

- NO PUSHING

- NO TELLING OFF

* ZERO TOLERANCE*


By minimizing physical contact, we minimize injuries and violence.


         “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.


Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!

We encourage competitive, but safe play. 

We reserve the right to ask anyone to leave who has exhibited any behavior that could be construed as violent, offensive, or dangerous. 

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game. 


Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board, 10 PM the night before to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

Location and Directions:

West End Presbyterian Church

165 West 105th Street, New York, NY

Near the lines: 1, 2, 3, B, and C trains.

AS YOU COME IN, TAKE THE STAIRS ON YOUR LEFT AND WALK TO THE 4TH FLOOR.

Call me if you can’t find us - (917)[masked] Manny S.


What to bring with you: 
A positive attitude, pair of sneakers or INDOOR shoes (ONLY), shin guards (recommended) and lots of water.

Fee: 
You will be asked to pay $9.25 dollars when you RSVP. This $9.25 dollars is used to pay for: permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, Goals, soccer balls etc.

Refund Policy:


* The Meetup is cancelled

* You can cancel at least 2 day(s) before the Meetup


Very IMPORTANT Due to the location where we will be playing:

We expect everyone to respect the facilities and act accordingly.

Anyone who is asked to leave will not be refunded and WILL be permanently banned from the group

After the game we can go for a quick drink at:

                                            TAP a KEG

                                         2731 Broadway

                                     New York, NY 10025

                            Betwee[masked]th and Broadway  

By RSVP'ing you agree to our Liability waiver:

PARTICIPATING IN MANHATTAN-INTERNATIONAL-COED-SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT:

results.description:
We're excited to be hosting our second Phoenix NYC meet-up later this month. Apologies for the date change, but the Feb Meet-Up will now be occurring on Mon Feb 29.


We'll be starting 30 minutes earlier this time in order to allow time for a brief 20 min intro to Phoenix presentation. I'll be starting this at pretty much 6:30 sharp in order to help make sure that new attendees are acquainted with Phoenix, so if you're not new to Phoenix you may want to wait to arrive until a little closer to 7PM.

The plan from 7-8 PM is to have 1-2 presentations (15-20mins), and 2-3 lightning talks (5-10 mins). If you have a presentation or lightning talk that you'd like to do, please send the organizers a message on meet-up or post it in the comments. It would be great to hear about others experience with the framework so far. If we don't receive any presentation suggestions, then I can do a presentation on 1 or 2 topics, and we can discuss what people are interested in.


From 8-9 PM we'll have a mix of some social Phoenix discussion and perhaps some coding (ideally including some contributions back to Phoenix :) -- this was a lot of fun last month.

We can also discuss the year ahead, including getting involved with contributing back to Phoenix, preferred meet-up times and locations, and plans for a regional Phoenix conference in NYC later this year. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or want to get involved.

results.description:
This month we are focusing on the evolution of shared spaces featuring Common and Projective Space.

Our featured speaker this month is General Assembly Co-Founder, Brad Hargreaves. Brad is joining us to share some of his team's experience developing their new startup, Common. Common is a flexible, community-driven housing providing fully furnished, month-to-month memberships, beginning in New York City. Learn more here:

• Brooklyn Startup Supplies the Apartment, Furniture, and Roommates

• This Brooklyn Co-Living Space Is Smarter Than NYC's Own Plan to Fix Its Housing Crisis

Run of show:
6:30 Doors Open
6:45 Food Served / Networking
7:05 Event Kickoff
7:15 Product Council w/ Projective Space (http://www.projective.co/­)
8:00 Break / Networking
8:10 Product Talk by Brad Hargreaves (http://www.hicommon.com/­)

Featured Product: Common

Our product tear down this month will feature folks from Projective Space, a curated members only community and co-working space for startups and entrepreneurs in NYC.

Product Hot Seat: Projective Space

- - - 

What is the Product Council? 

The Product Council provides startups and existing companies a fresh new outlet for critical feedback, ideation, and improvement of their products. Each month an audience of product makers (design, dev, etc.) and founders gather to learn valuable lessons and insights from experienced product owners as they dive deep into the challenge, success and failure of product design. This is no demo or pitch, rather it’s an open examination of how to execute an idea. 

Join us this month for your opportunity to exchange product stories, network, and learn valuable lessons from seasoned product veterans.

“I want to reiterate how much I enjoy Product Council events. You guys consistently host quality Meetups.” -Brandon


“The Meetup was excellent. In learning about practical approaches to product management, I'm able to better utilize my own product management toolbox to further develop an effective, productive and efficient product management system for our company. Thanks and I look forward to future Product Council meetups.” - Eric


Featured Product: Coming soon!


Featured Startup: Coming soon!

This month's Product Council: Coming soon!

- - - -

Ever wonder what it’s like to actually sit on the Product Council?  Look no further, one of our product council members documented his experience here, “Ouch, Product Feedback”.


Learn more on our blog: http://productcouncil.tumblr.com/

results.description:
Meet and network with startups and marketing colleagues, entrepreneurs, and decision-makers from a cross-section of industries, companies, and levels. Marketers from the following companies have attended in the past: Pepsi, L'Oreal, Pernod Ricard, Procter & Gamble, Colgate Palmolive, Rosetta, Young & Rubicam, Ogilvy, Havas, Thomson Reuters, Bloomingdale's, MTV, and American Express. 

Join us on Monday, February 29th from 6:30pm-8:30pm at Build Grand Central, part of Grand Central Tech. In addition to our standard happy hour, throughout the event, you'll be able to check out exhibition stations from various New York tech startups. We'll be providing free wine & beer. FoodtoEat will be providing delicious hors d'oeuvres.

Because we're hosting it at Build Grand Central, the building's security requires us to submit a list of the names of all attendees. Unfortunately, that means no walk-ins will be allowed and you must RSVP online by 3:30pm the day of the event. You'll be asked to provide your full name and email address when you RSVP for this event.

Meet the Exhibiting Startups 


- Loop Rides provides free rides and immersive brand experiences on our promotional vehicles. We build authentic campaigns that engage millions oftargeted consumers, providing them with a memorable service they will appreciate and share with friends.  By offering seven minutes of uninterrupted consumer engagement, we create unparalleled opportunities to foster emotional connections with passengers, ultimately building brand loyalty and turning triers into buyers. Available nationally, we have experience operating for major events, cross-market mobile tours, sponsorship activations, sampling tours and more.

- Loop & Tie helps busy professionals send awesome gifts. We know that one size doesn't fit all, so we designed the gift of choice. Our gift platform allows recipients to choose the gift they want from our curated collection of products or the company's own branded products and services. We’re not just about gifts, we’re about engagement. Our platform can be used to respond to thank you notes, build the relationship and improve brand loyalty. With automated gift sends and CRM integrations, we make gift giving efficient, organized and impactful for every business.

Remember to join our email list and follow us on Twitter. 

About Croud  
</a><a href="http://croud.com/">Croud is a performance digital marketing agency founded in the UK in July 2011, now ranked number 4 in Google’s Top 10 UK Independent Agencies. Croud launched in the US in late 2015 to support work on its US-based clients, including Netflix, Net-a-Porter, Regus, and Etsy, and to establish the agency as a major global player. Croud now employs 70 people globally across offices in New York, London, Shrewsbury, and Sydney but is powered in the back end by Croudies, its very own network of over 350 on-demand digital marketing professionals. This network allows the company to do more optimization per account than any other agency on the planet. 

About FoodtoEat 
FoodtoEat is a marketplace for companies to get catering from the best restaurants, food trucks and caterers. We impact the way people eat in the workplace by collaborating with the local food community to provide mindful food experiences. We strive to help amazing companies feed their talented employees because we believe that investing in your team is the best investment a company can make. Learn more: www.foodtoeat.com/p/catering

About Grand Central Tech  
Grand Central Tech is a community of startups and strategic partners that breaks from the traditional accelerator model by providing an unparalleled value proposition. Accepted companies will receive FREE office space for a YEAR with ZERO equity fee to participate. To support these companies, we have assembled an incredible group of Strategic Advisors, Mentors, Corporate Partners, Growth Partners, and Educational Institutions.

results.description:
Mandatory reading : Care of the Soul  (25th anniversary)

Author : Thomas Moore

Thomas Moore's Care of the Soul is an adventuresome meditation upon the sacred art of soulful living. The author, a psychotherapist, lived in a Catholic religious order for 12 years.

In the introduction, Moore describes the book as "a program for bringing soul back to life." What does he mean by soul? He writes: "Soul is not a thing but a quality or dimension of experiencing life and ourselves. It has to do with depth, value, relatedness, heart and personal substance." For him, soul is the seat of the emotions and the hub of our lives. Moore claims that a loss of soul lies behind the restlessness, addiction, insecurity, and frustration of so many contemporary men and women.

With lives devoid of meaning and purpose, people yearn for something to nourish their souls.

Thomas Moore is to be commended for providing a recipe for soulful living in troubled times. He helps us see that we can survive and learn from our personal troubles, tragedies, and follies. He proclaims that soul cannot be separated from body, family, work, love, or power. And by challenging us to care for our souls, Moore draws a bead on the bounties of spirituality. In the end, he calls us to our true vocation which is to care for the world's soul and to celebrate the sacred arts of life.

Care of the Soul  is an essential primer for those who want to relate spirituality to everyday life.

NOTE : When possible, please donate $3 to help defray the cost of Meetup.com. Thank you.

results.description:
You don’t need a team to reap the benefits of agile. Learn to apply some of the most powerful agile methodologies to your everyday work.

Are you intrigued by the benefits that agile techniques can bring to your work, but you work alone? Or do you want to become more productive in your individual role, but you work for an organization that has yet to embrace agile? This course will show you how to apply some of the most powerful agile techniques to your everyday work either as an individual or as a member of a traditional team. You’ll learn how to maximize your daily effort on the tasks that matter the most, better understand how much you can really finish during the day, and create a sustainable cadence in which your work will fit. And, you’ll learn to do this both at the small scale and the large scale, all while building a great product of your very own.

About the Author: Jeremy Jarrell is a software developer specializing in commercial application development for the enterprise space. He is heavily involved in the local developer community, both as a highly rated speaker throughout the east coast as well as a syndicated author whose articles have appeared on sites such as Simple-Talk.com and DZone.com. Jeremy's areas of specialization include agile development methodologies, team leadership, distributed architecture and web application security. He current resides in north central West Virginia with his wife and son and is an avid runner.

Ready to improve your French and/or English with native speakers? Or just meet and network with new people while helping them practicing your own language? Speak Easy — a language exchange -style evening of conversation hosted by French Morning — is just ce qu’il vous faut.

Half of participants are native French speakers and the other half native Anglophones. French Morning will take care of partnering you up so that the conversations can flow from the moment the evening gets underway.

results.description:
This month, let's go back to  Village Natural, a quiet and cozy West Village spot that offers a variety of mostly veggie and vegan dishes ranging from tofu teriyaki, spaghetti and wheat balls, enchiladas and fajitas to Moroccan cous-cous, sandwiches, veggie-burgers and freshly-prepared juices, and organic wines and beers.

Stuart will be our host and discussion leader, and the topic for the evening will be Dealing with Difficult People. Here is Stuart's introduction to the topic:

First, when we say "difficult people" we're not talking about people with foibles. None of us is an absolute delight to be around all the time. All of us have traits or habits that even our closest friends or loved ones wish they could abracadabra away into thin air. Difficult people are those whose presence is never welcome- even if you feel sorry for them. They can be, among other things, unreasonably demanding, egomaniacal, vulgar, boring, embarrassing to be around, unpleasant, depressing, etc. How do we deal with them? Do we try to avoid them? If we can't, do we set limits on our interactions with them? What do the demands of kindness and pity place on us? Do you ever try to correct or improve their behavior? And what about the difference between difficult people who are relative strangers, workmates, acquantances, family members and even those who were once friends?

It's sure to be a great discussion.
results.name: Dinner and Discussion on... Difficult people

results.description:
We have a JAM-PACKED night this Monday.  And, we hope you can join us as we plan for several upcoming events that will take place in March.  

6:30 PM:  Jay will lead a meeting of the newly formed Outings Committee.  This team won't be smashing any closets, but they will be planned events that take place outside our regular Monday evening venue.  Everyone is welcome to participate to hear what's is planned, and/or to make suggestions for future outings.  You may or may not choose join the committee, it's up to you, but we still want your input.

7:00 PM:  20-Somethings:  "All the World's a Stage:  Perceptions of LGBT People in the Media"  Join Nick, David, Kris, Dev and others as they discuss the current and retrospective views of how our personalities and lives have been displayed to the nation through the media.  

7:00 PM:  Open Talk, our most open and free discussion group will meet in the Library.  Anyone can pop-in, plop down, and share!  This week's discussion will be facilitated by Trustee Liz Slicer.  


Near the end of Open Talk, Jay will make presentations about two upcoming outings/Meetups.  For our first-ever participation in March 12th's St. Patrick's Parade through Morristown, we will be building two teams, Marchers and Supporters.  And, our 20-Somethings group will be hitting the lanes to enjoy an afternoon of bowling on the following Saturday, March 19th.  Some from the 30+ crowd have also expressed interest in bowling, so if there is someone who wants to organize another "team," let us know.

8:00 PM:  Rant-a-Palooza!
What’s the burr under your saddle? What makes your heart sing? This is your chance to take a GAAMC Minute to tell us all about it. Don’t know how long a GAAMC Minute is? Same as a regular minute with an interesting sound effect if you go over…it’s one of our most popular events and it’s great practice for organizing your thoughts and saying your piece succinctly so everyone gets a shot at fame!

Remember all those topics Mom said weren't to be discussed in polite company? Well, that's exactly what you should bring to vent into the brisk February air. Let it fly! Good stuff, bad stuff, irritating stuff, let it rip!
results.name: Huge night at GAAMC!

results.description:
CHECK IT OUT FOR ONLY $5 BUCKS! 


Welcome To The Writer’s Room 
 This is the only class of its kind—run like a real writer’s room on a 30 minute TV comedy series, taught by a professional showrunner with over 25 years of industry experience—and featuring the work of 12 talented student writers. You’ll not only learn how to write a half hour spec episode or pilot that can open the door to a job in Hollywood, you’ll actually write one for the show of your choice, and collaborate on the development of a script for a different show each week, just like they do in the big leagues.

What You’ll Learn
You’ll learn the elements of a successful half-hour comedy series, and how to write a pilot or spec episode that shows off your ability to create what every network, studio, and series producer is looking for: a professional grade script plays within the structure of the series for which you want to write, while showing off your unique talent as a writer. You’ll not only have real world experience of working in a TV writer’s room, you’ll also connect with a community of writers you can depend on, and the knowledge you need to write a professional grade pilot you can use to pursue a career in Hollywood. A Teacher You Can Trust With more than 25 years of Hollywood experience, Jerome has been a showrunner, writer, and producer on some of the most successful half-hour series in history, including “The Jeffersons,” “The Golden Girls,” “Frasier,” “The Nanny,” and “Married…with Children.” Now, he brings a lifetime of experience directly to you as your teacher, showrunner, mentor and coach.

Learn more.

NORMAL COST: $899

MEETUP MEMBERS: Check out the first day of this  10-week workshop for only $5 bucks with no obligation!

Class Size is Strictly Limited To 12 Students To Allow All Students The Opportunity to Workshop And Receive Feedback On Their Writing. 

You MUST RSVP to attend this event.

You'll LOVE this workshop or your money back!

--who your potential audience is (and what kind of readers you'd ideally like in your group)
--Where in the process you are*
--what kind of schedule you would like. (i.e. assuming each group looks at 3-4 pieces of 10-15 pages (double spaced) each time, do you want to read and submit once a month? once a week? Have more feedback and less submissions (with maybe 8 people in a group instead of 4?)

Hopefully, but the end, we will have several working groups of 4-8 people, and you can all trade info, commit to a time (I would recommend 6-8 weeks) and have each other's contact information. (I don't think these should be posted on Meetup, because anyone can come to Meetup--these are committed working groups.)


* Linda Joy Meyers defines three phases that I think are useful for full-length works. We might also have a group working on short essays.
*Kick-starting: "You are beginning to learn what your story is trying to become. You discover significant moments that create the spine of your memoir. You clarify your themes and free-write your memories. You learn about sorting through themes and topics, character development and how to sketch an outline for the rest of your book. In this stage you get acquainted with what a memoir requires of you and what it will give back.

The Muddy Middle: In this stage you start to question why are are writing a memoir. Self-doubt and the inner critic start whispering in your ear, and yet you're also learning a lot--about yourself, the past, and the kind of structure and story line your memoir needs. Doubts that have to do with memory, family, and truth come up at this time. You learn how to affirm yourself and your writing. You learn to find the structure that your memoir needs during this stage, and how to write your way to the end of a first draft. This stage is long, exciting, tiring and exhilarating. It's a ride that gets you to "the End."

* Birthing your book: This is the later phase of writing your memoir, the home stretch. By now you know your story, you have solved many of the problems of ploy and memory and you've made your way through various bouts of self-doubt. Your story has helped to teach you the focus of your work and you have learned many writing skills by this stage. You have a clear sense of what you are writing about. You are past the Muddy Middle. You can see "the End" looming. You are celebrating, and you are beginning to think about editing and building a platform, and you're continuing to read memoirs that feed your learning curve. You learn to become your own editor in the revision process, which is a part of this stage, and you're in the process of deciding how you want to have your books published.

results.description:
• Awaken your body and mind’s innate healing powers 
• Develop healthier and more fulfilling relationships 
• Learn to work constructively with your own emotions 
• Stimulate your minds innate problem solving capabilities 
• Develop new resources and capabilities 
• Become clear about your life’s purpose 
Develop your intuition by tapping into the innate intelligence that resides within your body and mind 
Our bodies communicate with us all the time. Many of us are so over stimulated and stressed out that we cannot hear what our bodies are saying. We age faster and suffer many health problems when we do not know how to listen to what our body is telling us. 
Discover the amazing wisdom that resides within your own body. Ben will show you how to develop your sensory awareness. Learn to truly listen to your body and care for its needs. 
Stimulate the mind's creative problem solving capabilities by learning to "digest" issues, emotions and stresses 
Many of us have never learned how to work with difficult issues and emotions. We tend to push these things down inside of ourselves. Undigested thoughts, issues, emotions and the stresses of daily life create a residue that accumulates within the tissues and organs of our bodies. That creates a great deal of additional stress upon our body and mind. These stresses can arrest our process of development, disconnect us from the divine creative intelligence of the universe and shut down our intuition. It also causes our bodies break down at a more rapid pace and that accelerates the aging process.

Learn to use your body-mind's innate healing power to "digest and assimilate" your thoughts feelings, emotions, issues and life experiences. You will begin to release the stresses that are held within the body and to heal the painful emotions associated with anxiety, depression and emotionally traumatic experiences. You will also learn to go right to the source of the issues to bring about a resolution that allows you to really move forward in your life. 
Working with these practices helps to increase your intellectual and emotional range, improve memory, initiate new cycles of growth, awaken inner passions, spark creativity and deepen intuition. You will develop the strength and resilience that will make it easier for you to adapt to the demands that life places upon you. 
Discover the passion and power that resides within you 
Chinese Martial Arts Masters emphasize the development of a base of power known as the "dan tien". The stress of living in such a fast paced world can cause us to disconnect from our foundation. Undigested food, emotions and the stresses of daily life begin to accumulate within the abdomen. We may experience bloating and suffer from various digestive problems. Some of us begin to lose touch with our drive, passion, inspiration and the sense of knowing that reveals our true purpose as our instinctual base shuts down.

You will learn to become fully present within your body, to develop greater personal power, and to awaken the inner passion and sense of knowing that will bring give you a greater sense of clarity about your life's purpose.

Activate the healing intelligence that resides within the body and mind 
We all have a powerful healing intelligence that resides within our bodies and minds. This innate healing power helps to mend our bodies any time we suffer an illness or injury. Our innate healing powers are often compromised by the stress and toxins that accumulate within our bodies. 
Learn to activate the generative healing powers that reside within your own body and mind. Awaken the consciousness of the individual organs. Access and heal the emotions and core issues that are held within the body. These practices are very effective for healing digestive and respiratory disorders and a wide range of other health issues.


Ben was drawn to indigenous cultures from an early age and found himself living among the Kiowa Tribe in Oklahoma at the age of seventeen. He began his training with Horace Daukei, the last surviving traditional doctor (medicine man) among the Kiowa Tribe. Ben went on to study with Chinese Master Li Tai Liang. He continues to train intensively in the Chinese systems of xin yi, bagua, tai chi and chi gong.

Please go to http://www.doiohm.com... or call (913)[masked] for more information

I'm working out in the field much of the time and I have very limited access to the internet. Please call me at (913)[masked] if you have any questions and are interested in attending. I will be happy to answer any questions that you have about how you can awaken the healing powers that reside within your own body and mind. Let me know in advance about your individual needs and concerns and we will address these issues during class.

FANGORIA is be hosting a special free screening of CAMINO!


</a>

Here's the skinny on CAMINO…

“Set in 1985, war photographer Avery Taggert (Bell) has built a solid career with her stark and honest imagery, all the while remaining emotionally distant from her subjects. When she embeds in the jungles of Colombia with a squad of missionaries led by a beloved and charismatic Spaniard known as ‘El Guero’ (Nacho Vigalondo of TIMECRIMES), she finds herself in the middle of a conflict as violent as any she’s photographed. One night, she happens upon El Guero committing a heinous atrocity, capturing the vile act on film, an image with the potential to discredit and destroy El Guero. Knowing this brilliant psychopath will employ every tactic at his disposal to destroy that photograph—and the photographer who took it—Avery flees into the harsh jungle with nothing but the camera hanging around her neck to escape from missionaries twisted into violent guerrillas by the madman intent on destroying all enemies.”


<a href="http://www.fangoria.com/new/nyc-free-camino-screening-coming-on-february-29th">www.fangoria.com/new/nyc-free-camino-screening-coming-on-february-29th

<a href="http://www.fangoria.com/new/nyc-free-screening-of-action-thriller-close-range-hits-on-november-30th"></a>

Josh C. Waller, who also directed Bell in the horror thriller RAZE, will be attending the show and taking part in a special Q&A!!

The Fango screening of CAMINO will be a free show; to obtain tickets, send an e-mail to [masked]. You must list “CAMINO” as your subject line and provide us your full name. Offer is good for you and one guest. Names will be checked at the door. Offer is first come, first served. Seating is Not guaranteed. This exclusive event is presented by our pals at XLrator Media, who releases CAMINO to theaters on March 4th and iTunes and VOD on March 8th.

Fango editor emeritus Tony Timpone will be hosting the show, plus expect some extra surprises.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_RSiNfQVAms

Please join us for the first NY Kid Tech Meetup of 2016! 

Our topic: Kids Who Code

Join us as we learn about Scratch, the free programming language for kids developed by a team at MIT, from the young people who use it every day.

Zach, 12, has been using Scratch since its inception and will provide insight into how he uses it, what he's created with the tool, and give feedback on its appeal.

Amy Kraft has been teaching Scratch to elementary age kids for the past year. She will showcase how students including her daughter have been using Scratch as an art creation tool.

The presentation will begin promptly at 7pm, and as always, we will have time for introductions and networking!

results.description:
It's been a while since we've had an event, so we are going back to our roots -- a hands-on study group on the iOS ResearchKit framework!

This study group is for you if:

* You are a researcher interested in ResearchKit, and open to getting your hands dirty with coding

* You are a developer working with ResearchKit, or interested in exploring the potential of the framework

* You just really, really want to code a research study for iPhone

The study group welcomes programmers of all levels, even absolute beginners, but the expectation is that you want to learn the framework, and how to build apps on it, hands-on. If you've never built an iPhone app before, please make sure you've satisfied the following requirements on your own before attending:

* Install XCode on your laptop

* Go through the Ray Wenderlich tutorial, or something similar: http://www.raywenderlich.com/104575/researchkit-tutorial-with-swift

* Bring your laptop to the Study Group (duh)


If you haven't done those things yet, don't worry! We are planning on making this a bi-weekly event, so you can just take your time on the tutorial and attend the next one.

I have to give you access to the building to get into Cornell Tech, so please make sure you e-mail me your full name, if you plan on attending: [masked]


Additional resources:

Getting Started Guide & Code: https://github.com/ResearchKit/ResearchKit#gettingstarted

ResearchKit Documentation: http://researchkit.org/docs/docs/Overview/GuideOverview.html

ResearchKit API Reference: http://researchkit.org/docs/index.html

Ray Wenderlich tutorial: http://www.raywenderlich.com/104575/researchkit-tutorial-with-swift

How to create a new ResearchKit “Active Task”:

http://blog.shazino.com/articles/dev/researchkit-new-active-task/

results.description:
Chers ami(e)s,

Thank you for making our now WEEKLY event "Jadore le French" a great success : c’était ma première surprise partie :-) Pictures posted below ! Let's meet again at Cellar Bar to speak French (or at least try a bit with Manhattans).

Special Thanks&HugsⓇ to the new members : you guys rock !Congratulations to Gabor and Abderaman, winners of the last raffle.

MegaHugsⓇ to Amelia, Hostess Etincelante, inventor of a new game using French quotes. 

French is not such a difficult language. If Rocky Balboa can speak Russian, if Rambo can speak Dari, then everybody can speak French, just a question of time :-) The new format "Jadore-le-French" is even nicer than our "Pardon-my-French" of last year.

To facilitate connections and meet&greets, we will have a special fun "lottery" :

Each of you will be given one of my polaroids (http://myinstantfilms.com/). Only TWO PAIRS will be identical. The 4 winners will get an invitation for two at Crepes & Delices, a brand new French crêperie located on 72nd and Columbus. THEY DO HAVE REAL GALETTES DE SARRASIN, AVIS AUX AMATEURS :

http://crepesanddelices.com


Come and get rewards by :

1. Dressing super nicely

2. Showing progress in your French skills (whatever you start from)

None of these are an obligation, neither a demand, just an incentive for rewards (perfumes, hats, free bottles of wine etc.).

Who are the organizers ? Yara, Handsome President, and Jean-Philippe, Glorieux Président. Since 3 weeks, Amelia, aka Superamelia, has joined the team as Hostess Étincelante.

IN THREE YEARS, WE HAVE ORGANIZED HUNDREDS OF SOCIAL EVENTS, FRENCH LESSONS/WORKSHOPS, FRENCH CONCERTS (including launching Flo, now superstar!) etc.

Pics from last Jadore le French :

Merci beaucoup et à lundi prochain !

-- Jean-Philippe, Yara, Amelia

results.description:
Join us for our weekly figure drawing session at The National Arts Club.

This session is open to all levels. Open to the public.

<a>Let us know you're coming.</a> 


We operate on a first come first served basis. Arriving by 6:45 is a good way to guarantee a seat.

• Bring your own drawing supplies.


• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• We have coffee and cookies at the long break.

• We finish on time so you can be headed home at 9:00 p.m sharp!

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.)

• We start with short 2 minute poses and work up to a 20 minute pose by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes.

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there.

Simon
